title: Choosing Domestic Services: What to Know About Cleaning, Maternity Care, and Part-Time Help
section: Domestic services—encompassing professional cleaning, maternity nursing, and part-time (hourly) help—play a vital role in simplifying household management, especially for busy families, new parents, or individuals with demanding schedules. These services offer tailored support, from maintaining a clean home to caring for newborns and assisting with daily chores. This article breaks down the key types of domestic services, their benefits, how to hire reliably, and answers to common questions.
content: What Are Domestic Services?

Domestic services refer to paid, professional assistance for household tasks, ranging from routine cleaning to specialized care. Unlike casual help, these services are typically provided by trained individuals or agencies, ensuring consistency, reliability, and expertise. The three most common categories are:
• Cleaning services
• Maternity nurses (postnatal care providers)
• Part-time/hourly workers (handypersons for daily tasks)
1. Professional Cleaning Services

Professional cleaners handle regular or one-time cleaning tasks, using specialized tools and techniques to maintain a hygienic home. They are ideal for busy professionals, families, or anyone needing consistent upkeep.
What Do They Do?
• Routine cleaning: Weekly or biweekly tasks like dusting, vacuuming, mopping floors, cleaning bathrooms (toilets, showers, sinks), and wiping kitchen surfaces.
• Deep cleaning: Thorough, occasional cleaning (e.g., seasonal) including hard-to-reach areas (window tracks, behind appliances), carpet shampooing, or oven cleaning.
• Specialized services: Post-construction cleanup, move-in/move-out cleaning, or eco-friendly cleaning (using non-toxic products).
Hiring Options
• Agency-based cleaners: Employed by a company, which handles scheduling, training, and insurance. More expensive but offers replacements if the cleaner is unavailable.
• Independent cleaners: Self-employed individuals, often with lower rates. Requires direct communication and management.
Costs
• Routine cleaning: 25–50 per hour, depending on home size (e.g., 100–200 for a 3-bedroom house).
• Deep cleaning: 50–100% higher than routine rates due to extra time and effort.
Tips for Hiring
• Check reviews or ask for referrals from neighbors/friends.
• Confirm insurance coverage (to protect against accidental damage).
• Specify tasks in advance (e.g., "focus on the kitchen and bathrooms") to avoid misunderstandings.
2. Maternity Nurses (Postnatal Care Providers)

Maternity nurses (or postnatal carers) specialize in supporting new parents during the first weeks or months after childbirth, focusing on infant care and maternal recovery. They are not medical professionals but offer practical and emotional support.
What Do They Do?
• Newborn care: Feeding (bottle or breastfeeding assistance), diaper changes, bathing, soothing, and establishing sleep routines.
• Maternal support: Helping with postnatal recovery (e.g., preparing meals, light housework), offering breastfeeding guidance, and emotional reassurance.
• Household help: Limited to baby-related tasks (e.g., sterilizing bottles) and light meal prep for parents.
Types of Maternity Nurses
• Live-in nurses: Stay in the home (24/7 or 12-hour shifts) for 2–6 weeks, ideal for first-time parents needing round-the-clock support.
• Live-out nurses: Visit daily for 4–8 hours, suitable for families who need structured help but prefer privacy.
Costs
• Live-in: 200–400 per day (varies by experience and location).
• Live-out: 30–60 per hour, with a minimum 4-hour daily booking.
Hiring Considerations
• Verify experience with newborns (e.g., premature babies, twins) if applicable.
• Check for CPR certification and background checks (critical for in-home care).
• Discuss expectations upfront (e.g., "Do you handle night shifts?" "Can you cook vegetarian meals?").
3. Part-Time/Hourly Domestic Workers
Part-time or hourly workers (often called "handypersons" or "domestic helpers") assist with flexible, non-specialized tasks, filling gaps in daily household management.
What Do They Do?
• Errands and chores: Grocery shopping, laundry, pet care, or picking up kids from school.
• Light cleaning: Basic tidying (less intensive than professional cleaners).
• Special tasks: Organizing closets, packing/unpacking, or assisting elderly family members with daily activities.
Flexibility
• Booked by the hour (2–8 hours) or for specific projects (e.g., "6 hours to organize the garage").
• Scheduled regularly (e.g., every Friday morning) or on an as-needed basis.
Costs
• 15–30 per hour, depending on tasks (e.g., pet care may be cheaper than organizing).
Benefits
• Ideal for irregular needs (e.g., after a party, during busy work weeks).
• More affordable than full-time help for occasional tasks.
How to Find Reliable Domestic Services
1. Use reputable platforms or agencies:
◦ Agencies vet workers (background checks, references) and handle scheduling/insurance.
◦ Online platforms with reviews (e.g., specialized domestic service websites) allow direct booking of independent workers.
1. Interview candidates:
◦ Ask about experience, availability, and handling specific scenarios (e.g., "How do you clean delicate surfaces?" or "What would you do if the baby won't stop crying?").
1. Sign a clear agreement:
◦ Outline tasks, hours, rates, cancellation policies, and confidentiality (especially for live-in roles).
1. Start with a trial period:
◦ Test a cleaner for 1–2 sessions or a maternity nurse for a few days to ensure compatibility.
FAQs About Domestic Services
• Q: Are domestic workers insured?

A: Agency workers are usually covered by the company's liability insurance (for accidents or damage). Independent workers may require you to purchase a separate policy, or you can ask for proof of their own insurance.
• Q: Can I request specific products (e.g., eco-friendly cleaners)?
A: Yes—most cleaners will use your preferred products if provided, though some may charge extra for specialized supplies.
• Q: What if I'm not satisfied with the service?
A: Agencies often offer replacements or refunds for poor service. With independent workers, clarify a "satisfaction guarantee" in advance (e.g., "Re-cleaning if tasks are incomplete").
• Q: Do maternity nurses need medical training?
A: No, but many have certifications in newborn care, breastfeeding support, or first aid. For medical needs (e.g., premature infants), consider a certified nurse midwife or pediatric nurse.
• Q: How far in advance should I book a maternity nurse?
A: 2–3 months before the due date, especially during peak periods (e.g., after holidays), as experienced nurses book up quickly.
Choosing the Right Service for Your Needs
• Cleaning services: Best for consistent home upkeep or one-time deep cleans.
• Maternity nurses: Essential for new parents needing expert postnatal support.
• Part-time workers: Perfect for flexible, on-demand help with errands or light chores.

By understanding the scope, costs, and hiring process for each service, you can simplify household management and focus on what matters most—whether that's work, family, or recovery. With the right domestic help, maintaining a balanced, stress-free home life becomes far more achievable.
